resources.string: Removes the ad across all the applications

Tip : Firewall prevents apps from accessing the Internet over Wifi or Mobile data. Since most forms of surveillance require the data to be sent over to a central repository, firewalling them effectively mitigates the threat. \n\nThere\'s a class of apps that require Internet connection all day, and those are usually communication apps like Gmail and messenger apps like WhatsApp. Firewalling them might not be an option, and that\'s why we built content blockers.

This permission is required to programmatically set DNS for your device. Think of DNS as an address book for the internet: It translates domains (for example, dns.google.com) to valid IP addresses (for example, 8.8.8.8). Setting it allows us to control out-going connections from any app on your device, thereby effectively preventing connections to blacklisted domains.
Helps automatically set a DNS based content blocker which helps with blocking trackers across the device.
Ready to set dns based content blocker.
Content blocker no longer in effect.
We use accessibility to automate frequent actions to manage security and privacy related settings on your phone.
Refuse connections to malicious websites and servers: Fake websites often steal critical personal information like bank accounts and passwords to emails.

Firewall prevents apps from accessing the Internet over Wifi or Mobile data. Since most forms of surveillance require the data to be sent over to a central repository, firewalling them effectively mitigates the threat

Apps are often granted permissions to access location or storage, for instance, that could be revoked once they have served the purpose. This is tedious; however, to do it manually. Permissions Manager helps with automating this task.

View reports on your Phone or on your PC. Since most forms of data collection involve sharing it to a central repository, this capbility might be handy to verify for yourself to single out behaviour of such apps.

string.name: warning_title
string.description: Status indicator text shown in a warning notification.

string.name: notification_content
string.description: Indicates what will happen if the user taps the notification.

string.name: warning_channel_name
string.description: This is the name of the class of notifications that show warnings. It's only visible in the system's advanced notifications settings page.

string.name: warning_channel_description
string.description: This is the explanatory text describing the 'Warning' notification class. It's only visible in the system's advanced notifications settings page.

resources.string: Shown when Brave has encountered a problem.

string.name: unknown_server
string.description: This is a placeholder, used when the server address is unknown.

string.name: query_label
string.description: This text appears under the domain name for which a DNS query was issued.

string.name: type_label
string.description: This text appears under the type of query that was issued ('A' or 'AAAA').

string.name: latency_label
string.description: This text appears under a measurement of network latency, like '923 ms'.

string.name: resolver_label
string.description: This text appears under a two-letter ISO country code, indicating the country where the DNS resolver is located.

string.name: destination_label
string.description: This text appears under a two-letter ISO country code, indicating the country where the resolved domain's IP address is located.

string.name: notification_title
string.description: Status indicator text shown in a persistent notification.

resources.string: Protected! Connected to Fast and Secure DNS.

string.name: status_waiting
string.description: This text appears during the connection process if Intra needs user permission or the phone is offline.

string.name: status_failing
string.description: This text appears if the connection is currently not working correctly. [CHAR_LIMIT=NONE]

string.name: explanation_offline
string.description: Status indicator shown when there is no network connection.

resources.string: Your device is offline. Intra is waiting for a network connection.

string.name: explanation_vpn
string.description: Warning text shown on the main screen before the user starts Intra

resources.string: Brave has detected another VPN on your device. If you enable Intra, that VPN will be disabled. Brave is not as secure as a trusted VPN.
Warning: Queries are failing. You may want to choose a different server or restart Intra.

string.name: status_starting
string.description: This text briefly appears while starting.

string.name: explanation_starting
string.description: Corresponds to status_starting

resources.string: Hang tight. Intra is establishing a server connection.

string.name: system_details
string.description: This is the title of a section containing information on the system configuration and status.

string.name: status_protected
string.description: This is a large message in a reassuring color. It indicates that DNS queries can't be surveilled or modified in transit.

string.name: explanation_protected
string.description: Expanded form of status_protected

resources.string: Your connection is protected from DNS attacks.

string.name: status_upgraded
string.description: This is similar to status_exposed, and indicates weak protection that an attacker could disable.

string.name: explanation_upgraded
string.description: Corresponds to status_upgraded.

resources.string: Your connection is currently protected by Android Private DNS, but an attacker could disable or undermine this protection.

string.name: status_strict
string.description: This is similar to dns_on, but the protection is being provided by the operating system, not by Intra. It is not color-highlighted.

string.name: explanation_strict
string.description: Explanation on the main screen for users who have Private DNS strict mode enabled at the OS level.

resources.string: Brave has detected that the Android Private DNS setting is enabled. This means your DNS queries are already protected, so there\'s no need to enable Intra.

string.name: status_exposed
string.description: This is a large message in a scary color. It indicates that DNS queries can be surveilled or modified in transit.

string.name: explanation_exposed
string.description: Expanded form of status_exposed

resources.string: Your connection is exposed to DNS attacks.

string.name: dns_explanation_connected
string.description: The message will be shown when the DNS is connected

string.name: dns_explanation_disconnected
string.description: This message will be shown to user in main screen when the DNS is not connected

string.name: firewall_explanation_text
string.description: Explanation on the main screen for the users about what the firewall does.

resources.string: Block apps or a category of apps from connecting to the Internet in response to device events: Limiting access to the Internet helps prevent unwarranted data usage as well as conserves battery.

string.name: app_mgr_explanation_text
string.description: Explanation on the main screen for the users about what the application manager does.

resources.string: Check which apps consume your data. Streamline your Android smartphone or tablet. Quickly and easily uninstall multiple unwanted applications.

string.name: network_queries_explanation_text
string.description: Explanation on the main screen for the users about network queries

resources.string: View DNS queries this device has requested. Typically, one request is sent for each Internet connection established by any app: For example, loading a web page can result in tens of DNS queries.

string.name: settings_explanation_text
string.description: Explanation on the main screen for the users for settings screen.

resources.string: A firewall to isolate apps completely from the Internet, or prevent them from making connections. Limiting access to the Internet helps prevent unwarranted data usage, as well as conserves battery.
All the applications will be firewalled when the phone is locked : Limiting background access to the Internet helps prevent unwarranted data usage as well as conserves battery.
Apply firewall rules on all installed applications based on device events, for example, firewall when the device is locked or when a particular app is not in use.

Choose application categories to firewall, for example, disallow the \'Games\' category to block internet access to all game apps. Note: These rules are applied independently of \'Universal Firewall\'.

Choose individually among installed applications to firewall, for example, firewall the \'Calculator\' app to disallow all internet access to it. Note: These rules are applied independently of \'Universal Firewall\'.
DNS+Firewall mode is not supported in your version of Android.

Protects from DNS manipulation attacks which is the most common way Internet is censored. Filters your network traffic with blacklists that power popular ad-blockers. Communication or messaging apps, for instance, can\'t be firewalled altogether, but can be, instead, blocked from accessing certain server endpoints of known ad networks and trackers.
Blocks apps from connecting to the Internet. Since most forms of surveillance require the data sent over the network to a server, firewalling them effectively mitigates the threat.
Filters your network traffic and blocks apps from connecting to Internet. This mode is available only on devices with Android 10 or higher versions.
We use accessibility to automate frequent actions to manage security and privacy related settings on your phone.
Cannot configure: Firewall Mode not active.
Cannot view logs: DNS Mode not active.
